facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 327 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 327 of 1965.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated July 4, 1962 of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 46 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order, dated July 4, 1962 of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 46 of 1960.

facts.text: In the account year ending November 6, 1953 Murlidhar Jhawar, Pannalal Lahoti and Govindbai carried on business in groundnut, companyton and companyton-seed.

anchor.surface_text: In the account year ending November 6, 1953 Murlidhar Jhawar, Pannalal Lahoti and Govindbai carried on business in groundnut, companyton and companyton-seed.

facts.text: In the year of assessment 1954-55 the Income-tax Officer, Nanded, brought to tax a third share in Rs. 51,280 computed as profits from the business in the hands of each of the three parties.

anchor.surface_text: In the year of assessment 1954-55 the Income-tax Officer, Nanded, brought to tax a third share in Rs. 51,280 computed as profits from the business in the hands of each of the three parties,

facts.text: Income-tax Officer called upon Murlidhar to submit a return of the income of the joint venture on the footing that the parties thereto constituted an unregistered firm.

anchor.surface_text: and thereafter he called upon Murlidhar to submit a return of the income of the joint venture on the footing that the parties thereto constituted an unregistered firm.

facts.text: Murlidhar complied with the requisition and submitted in November 1957 a return.

anchor.surface_text: Murlidhar complied with the requisition and submitted in November 1957 a return, but later applied to withdraw it by application dated December 18, 1957.

facts.text: Murlidhar applied to withdraw the return by application dated December 18, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Murlidhar complied with the requisition and submitted in November 1957 a return, but later applied to withdraw it by application dated December 18, 1957.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer rejected the application for withdrawal of return.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer rejected the application for withdrawal of return and completed the assessment

facts.text: Income-tax Officer completed the assessment of the three parties to the joint venture under S. 23(3) of the Income-tax Act, 1922 in the status of an unregistered firm and computed the income at Rs. 80,925.

anchor.surface_text: and completed the assessment of the three parties to the joint venture under S. 23 3  of the Income-tax Act, 1922 in the status of an unregistered firm and computed the income of the joint venture at Rs. 80,925.

facts.text: In appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner the order passed by the Income-tax Officer was confirmed.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner the order passed by the Income-tax Officer was confirmed.

facts.text: In second appeal, the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal set aside the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: In second appeal, the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal set aside the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Tribunal held that the Income-tax Officer had the option to assess the individual parties to the joint venture, and he having exercised that option it was not open to him thereafter to reassess the same income collectively in the hands of the three parties to the joint venture in the status of an unregistered firm.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held that the Income- tax Officer had the option to assess the individual parties to the joint venture, and he having exercised that option it was number open to him thereafter to reassess the same income- collectively in the hands of the three parties to the joint venture in the status of an unregistered firm.

facts.text: On a concession made by counsel for the three parties, the Tribunal directed that the assessment be rectified so as to restore the status quo ante.

anchor.surface_text: But on a concession made by counsel for the three parties, the Tribunal directed that the assessment be rectified so as to restore the status quo ante.

facts.text: Tribunal submitted a statement of the case and referred the question to the High Court of Judicature at Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal submitted a statement of the case and referred the following question to the High Court of Judicature at Bombay

facts.text: The question referred: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the assessment of the unregistered firm was proper and legal, the two partners of this partnership having been assessed in respect of their shares of income from this partnership business?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the assessment of the unregistered firm was proper and legal, the two partners of this partnership having been assessed in respect of their shares of income from this partnership business ?

facts.text: The High Court recorded an answer in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court recorded an answer in the negative.

facts.text: With certificate granted by the High Court, this appeal has been preferred.

anchor.surface_text: With certificate granted by the High Court, this appeal has been preferred.

facts.text: Pannalal and Govindbai were partners of Messrs. Purna Ginning Pressing Factory.

anchor.surface_text: The transactions in various commodities were carried on by Pannalal and Govindbai who were partners of Messrs. Purna Ginning Pressing Factory and by Murlidhar.

facts.text: The Income-tax Officer had assessed the income of the three parties separately and added to the individual income of each party his or her share in the profits of the joint venture.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer had assessed the income of the three parties separately and added to the individual income of each party his or her share in the profits of the joint venture.

facts.text: Mr. Viswanatha Sastri for the Department contends that the Income-tax Officer making the first assessment of the three parties to the joint venture was not informed that the three parties constituted an unregistered firm.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the assessment of the unregistered firm was proper and legal, the two partners of this partnership having been assessed in respect of their shares of income from this partnership business?

issues.text: Whether the Income-tax Officer had knowledge of the joint venture or unregistered firm such that his assessment of the individual shares constituted an exercise of the option to assess the individuals separately, precluding later assessment of the firm?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Viswanatha Sastri for the Department contends that the Income-tax Officer making the first assessment of the three parties to the joint venture was not informed that the three parties constituted an unregistered firm and therefore the Income-tax Officer was in law competent to assess the entity which was

arguments.claim: The Income-tax Officer had the option to assess the individual parties to the joint venture, and having exercised that option by assessing them individually, it was not open to him thereafter to assess the same income collectively in the hands of the three parties as an unregistered firm.

arguments.claim: Section 3 treats an association of persons or unregistered firm and its individual members as two distinct assessable entities; tax can be levied on either but not the same income twice.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 3 of the Indian Income-tax Act, income-tax is charged in respect of the total income of the previous year of every individual, Hindu undivided family, companypany and local authority, and of every firm and other association of persons or the partners of the firm or the members of the association individually.

arguments.claim: The income of the three parties was assessed under s. 23(3) of the Income-tax Act as it was earned in commercial transactions in different commodities.

anchor.surface_text: It would be reasonable to hold that the income of the three parties was assessed under s. 23 3  of the Income-tax Act, for the income was earned in companymercial transactions in different companymodities.

arguments.claim: The Income-tax Officer was cognizant of the joint venture income being taxable collectively but chose to assess provisionally separately subject to rectification.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer in assessing the income of the joint venture, companyld number have proceeded without scrutinizing the accounts and other relevant documentary evidence and without determining the skares of the three parties to the joint venture. ... the order of the Income-tax Officer clearly indicates that he was companynizant of the fact that the income of the joint venture was taxable companylectively

holdings.text: The section s. 3 expressly treats an association of persons and the individual members of an association as two distinct and different assessable entities. On the terms of the section the tax can be levied on either of the said two entities according to the provisions of the Act. The same principle would apply to the cases of assessment of partners individually of an unregistered firm. The partners may be assessed individually or they may be assessed collectively in the status of an unregistered firm the Income-tax Officer cannot however seek to assess the one income twice-once in the hands of the partners and again in the hands of the unregistered firm.

anchor.surface_text: The section s. 3 expressly treats an association of persons and the individual members of an association as two distinct and different assessable entities. On the terms of the section the tax can be levied on either of the said two entities according to the provisions of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation of s.3 IT Act following precedent in Kanpur Coal Syndicate; applies principle of distinct entities to unregistered firms prohibiting double assessment of same income.

holdings.text: When the Income-tax Officer assessed the three parties separately he unquestionably exercised an option knowing that they had entered into a trading transaction in which they were jointly interested.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer had assessed the income of the three parties separately and added to the individual income of each party his or her share in the profits of the joint venture.

holdings.reasoning_summary: ITO possessed information of joint venture from including profit shares in individual assessments; knowledge required for valid exercise of option per Bachulal Kapoor precedent.

holdings.text: It would be reasonable to hold that the income of the three parties was assessed under s. 23(3) of the Income-tax Act, for the income was earned in commercial transactions in different commodities.

anchor.surface_text: It would be reasonable to hold that the income of the three parties was assessed under s. 23 3  of the Income-tax Act, for the income was earned in companymercial transactions in different companymodities.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Nature of income from commercial transactions in multiple commodities fits s.23(3); distinguishes from provisional assessment under s.23B on common ground.

holdings.text: The order of the Income-tax Officer clearly indicates that he was cognizant of the fact that the income of the joint venture was taxable collectively, but he thought that he could in law in the first instance make an assessment provisionally of the three parties separately and then rectify the assessments later.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer in assessing the income of the joint venture, companyld number have proceeded without scrutinizing the accounts and other relevant documentary evidence and without determining the skares of the three parties to the joint venture. ... the order of the Income-tax Officer clearly indicates that he was companynizant of the fact that the income of the joint venture was taxable companylectively

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inference from assessment order noting provisional addition subject to rectification and scrutiny of accounts showing awareness of collective taxability.
